block.p: Major Market Gauges Drop On Interest Rates Concerns Stock prices fell after the government reported that factory orders in March were higher than expected and a Federal Reserve survey showed intensifying wage pressures. Both reports increased anxiety about the Fed's May 16 meeting, at which it is expected to raise interest rates for the sixth time since June.

The Dow Jones industrial average fell 250.99 points, or 2.3 percent, to 10,480.13. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 78.14 points, or 2.1 percent, to 3,707.31, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was off 31.19 points, or 2.2 percent, to 1,415.10. [Page C8.]

The yield on the two-year note rose to 6.74 percent and is the highest it has been in 5 years. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond jumped to 6.11 percent. [C8.]

Another Microsoft Executive Quits Nathan P. Myhrvold, the chief technology officer of Microsoft, announced that he will leave the software company. He had been on a leave of absence from Microsoft since last July, and many analysts predicted it would become permanent. ''I wasn't sure,'' he said. ''But, of course, there is always the possibility that when a guy takes a year off he'll find that other life more attractive.'' [C20.]

Mexico's Top Banks in Merger Talks Mexico's largest financial group, Banacci, has begun merger talks with Bancomer, the country's second-largest financial group. The entity that would result if the merger were successful would be Latin America's largest, with nearly $60 billion in assets. [C4.]

Murdoch Daughter to Leave BSkyB The 31-year-old daughter of Rupert Murdoch, Elisabeth Murdoch, is quitting the company her father controls, British Sky Broadcasting, at the end of June to start a media venture of her own in London. Her departure may signal the end of a rivalry between her and her two brothers, Lachlan and James, to succeed their father as chairman of the News Corporation, which owns 40 percent of BSkyB, which is Europe's No. 2 pay television concern. [C4.]

Disney Profits Exceed Expectations Profits rose 66 percent at the Walt Disney Company on higher advertising sales at ABC. Net income jumped to $161 million, or 8 cents a share, from adjusted earnings of $97 million, or 5 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Excluding Go.com, Disney earned 18 cents a share; analysts had expected 14 cents. Still, its shares fell $1.25, to $41.25. Revenue rose 14 percent, to $6.2 billion. [C2.]

Metallica Pursues Napster Fight Representatives of the heavy-metal band Metallica went to the headquarters of Napster with 13 boxes of papers said to list more than 300,000 computer users who recently had downloaded Metallica music without the band's permission. Napster said it would review the papers and take steps to disable those users Metallica identified if the claims had been properly submitted. [C20.]

New Bottle, New Ads for Lipton Lipton's Iced Tea, seeking to shore up its eroding market share, will soon have a new bottle and a new campaign, its first major advertising effort for the brand in four years. The strategy is to differentiate Lipton's Iced Tea, which has a 9.5 percent share of sales of all ready-to-drink bottled and canned teas, from its main competitor, Snapple, which has a 14.6 percent share. Advertising. [C7.]

Magazine Industry Honors Itself In a rough year for the magazine industry, the tone at the National Magazine Awards presentation could have been one of uncertainty. Instead, the ceremony, which held a few surprises, sounded more like an evening of stand-up comedy. [C7.]
